ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved my German significantly (reading the novel in German) and learned a lot about mid 20th century Vienna and general modernist literature in the German-speaking world.
This course centered on a semester-long reading of a seminal novel of Austrian modernism, The Strudlhof Steps by Heimito von Doderer.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think that this class was at its strongest when it was organized around a clear and "obvious" theme or focus: close reading certain passages (because in the part is found the wholeat least in the best written parts). However, I fear that this class often had an unmoored quality to it. We did speak very often in what felt like generalities, and I wish we had more referring to page numbers instead of relying on generalized memories of the text.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would definitely recommend this course to another student. The text is unlike many other texts I have read, so it was very cool to spend a whole semester reading and studying it. It is also a very long book, so it felt very rewarding to read the whole thing! Professor Wetters and the other students in the class always made sure that class discussion was interesting and captivating. We were also able to meet the translator of the book, which was an amazing experience. The only caveat is that because the book is so long, it is easy to fall behind on reading assignments, which makes class more difficult to follow.
For sure! I was amazed at how relevant the novel is to a variety of majors/disciplines.

I would. Kirk is an expert in his field and such a wonderful person to take classes with. Doderer's text is also really interesting. I do think that in order to get a lot out of this class, one needed to have a focus or "way" one wanted to approach the bookand it helps to have some background in other modernist novels, at least in a limited fashion. Also, we had the translator of the text come to class! That was awesome! Definitely the highlight of the course, by far. So rich and so fulfilling.
